H0.text: Suu Kyi, who was sentenced to home detention for six years in 2003, is the Leader of the Opposition in which country. Thailand

H1.text: Suu Kyi, who was sentenced to home detention for six years in 2003, is the Leader of the Opposition in which country. Cambodia

H2.text: Suu Kyi, who was sentenced to home detention for six years in 2003, is the Leader of the Opposition in which country. Vietnam

H3.text: Suu Kyi, who was sentenced to home detention for six years in 2003, is the Leader of the Opposition in which country. Birma

A4.text: After her hysterectomy in September 2003, the government again placed her under house arrest in Rangoon.

A5.text: The government imprisoned her at Insein Prison in Rangoon.

A6.text: Aung San Suu Kyi is the leader of the National League for Democracy.

A7.text: On 6 April 2016, Aung San Suu Kyi assumed the newly created role of state counsellor, a role akin to a prime minister.

A8.text: Aung San Suu Kyi's NLD party participated in the 2012 by-elections, facilitated by the government's abolition of the laws that previously barred it.

A9.text: The 2015 Myanmar general election led to improved foreign relations and eased economic sanctions.

A10.text: The military government placed Aung San Suu Kyi under house arrest again on 31 May 2003, following an attack on her convoy in northern Burma.

A11.text: Myanmar general elections were held on 8 November 2015.

A12.text: Suu Kyi was sentenced to imprisonment for three years with hard labour in 2009.

A13.text: The National League for Democracy is Myanmar's main opposition party.

A14.text: According to the results announced by the Union Election Commission on 13 November 2015, the NLD won 238 seats in the lower house and 348 seats in the Pyidaungsu Hluttaw, exceeding the required number to form a government and elect a president.

A15.text: The results gave the National League for Democracy an absolute majority of seats in both chambers of the national parliament, enough to ensure that its candidate would become president, while NLD leader Aung San Suu Kyi is constitutionally barred from the presidency.

A16.text: General Ne Win's Legacy of Burmanization in Myanmar
